commit_message:
Specify what to do if endpoint map environment don't match

this attempts to make the error message more useful. This error message
happens if the environment files containing endpoint map overrides
haven't been updated to match the base endpoint map (or the defaults).

Change-Id: If53d3a9d7848aed62ebb235afe8b14c18d1b284d
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates refs/changes/89/424789/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: print("ERROR: %s needs to be updated to match changes in base " "endpoint map" % env_endpoint_map['file'])
deleted_lines: print("ERROR: %s doesn't match base endpoint map" % env_endpoint_map['file'])

commit_message:
Add disable_upgrade_deployment flag to roles_data.yaml

As part of the composable upgrades current plan is to disable
the composable upgrades steps running on a particular role
(e.g. all compute nodes) in favor of a later operator driven
upgrades process as has previously been the case

This adds the disable_upgrade_deployment flag to roles_data as
a first step. Thanks to shardy for his help with this.

Change-Id: Ice845742a043b34917e61f662885786c73e955fd
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates refs/changes/44/418344/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: UpgradeExcludeNodes: type: list description: > List of nodes, by nova name ([overcloud-compute-0, overcloud-compute-3]) for which the upgrade is skipped. No upgrade configuration will be defined or applied for those nodes during the given stack update. default: [] servers: yaql: expression: dict($.data.servers_param.where($ != null).flatten().selectMany($.items()).where($.name not in $.data.exclude_list)) data: servers_param: - {get_param: [servers, {{role.name}}]} exclude_list: - {get_param: UpgradeExcludeNodes}

Change-Id: I86435a216c9c8d8bd391fb662049662d7d303ae5

commit_message:
Eliminate reference to metadefs 'namespace_id'

In most places, the api-ref refers to the 'namespace_name' in URLs,
but in two places in the metadefs-namespaces-properties file, the
term 'namespace_id' is used.  This patch fixes those two occurrences
in the interest of consistency, but also because it is causing a
warning that's interpreted as an error in the latest version of
os_api_ref [0].

[0] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2017-January/110606.html

Change-Id: I86435a216c9c8d8bd391fb662049662d7d303ae5
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/glance refs/changes/95/424295/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. rest_method:: POST /v2/metadefs/namespaces/{namespace_name}/properties - namespace_name: namespace_name

revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2017-01-24 16:01:20.000000000', 'files': ['neutron_fwaas/extensions/firewall.py', 'neutron_fwaas/tests/unit/extensions/test_firewall.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron-fwaas/commit/0f02e18a4505bff06e7dd1eb0fb5ec4e48921df5', 'message': "Fix validation in converting 'protocol'

Change-Id: Ie2a61b744decaad0fe168669d1a9df47633a0608
Closes-Bug: #1659031

commit_message:
Fix validation in converting 'protocol'

This commit fixes validation in converting 'protocol' for firewall_rule
from integer or integer of string value.  Ex. it is possible to specify
'6' or 6 as a 'protocol'.

Change-Id: Ie2a61b744decaad0fe168669d1a9df47633a0608
Closes-Bug: #1659031
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron-fwaas refs/changes/16/424716/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def test_convert_protocol_string_integer(self): def test_convert_protocol_digit(self): res = firewall.convert_protocol(0) self.assertEqual(0, res) res = firewall.convert_protocol(255) self.assertEqual(255, res) def test_convert_protocol_another_types(self): res = lambda: firewall.convert_protocol(['abc']) self.assertRaises(firewall.FirewallRuleInvalidProtocol, res) res = lambda: firewall.convert_protocol({1: 'foo'}) self.assertRaises(firewall.FirewallRuleInvalidProtocol, res) res = lambda: firewall.convert_protocol((1, 100)) self.assertRaises(firewall.FirewallRuleInvalidProtocol, res) res = lambda: firewall.convert_protocol(object) self.assertRaises(firewall.FirewallRuleInvalidProtocol, res)

commit_message:
Remove dogpile.core dependencies

Library dogpile.cache supersedes dogpile.core [1] since version
0.6.0. Current required version is dogpile.cache>=0.6.2

[1] https://media.readthedocs.org/pdf/dogpilecache/latest/dogpilecache.pdf

Change-Id: I6ddeba6b05f7b4616892a7405ea66a301477d993

commit_message:
Routed networks IPv4 inventory in Nova GRP

Using Nova's generic resource pools (GRP) API, publish routed networks
IPv4 inventory. This inventory is then used by the Nova scheduler to
place instances based on the availability of IPv4 addresses in
routed networks segments.

Change-Id: Ib6b00c4889d6a34765844ce46280819dff0108c5
Partially-Implements: blueprint routed-networks
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/58/358658/33 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import netaddr from keystoneauth1 import loading as ks_loading from novaclient import client as nova_client from oslo_config import cfg from placementclient import client as placement_client from placementclient import exceptions as placement_exceptionsfrom neutron.callbacks import events from neutron.callbacks import registry from neutron.callbacks import resourcesNOVA_API_VERSION = '2' NOVA_PLACEMENT_API_VERSION = '1' IPV4_RESOURCE_CLASS = 'IPV4_ADDRESS' SEGMENT_NAME_STUB = 'Neutron segment id %s' self.nova_updater = NovaSegmentNotifier() class NovaSegmentNotifier(object): def __init__(self): auth = ks_loading.load_auth_from_conf_options(cfg.CONF, 'nova') session = ks_loading.load_session_from_conf_options( cfg.CONF, 'nova', auth=auth) self.p_client = placement_client.Client( NOVA_PLACEMENT_API_VERSION, session=session, region_name=cfg.CONF.nova.region_name, endpoint_type=cfg.CONF.nova.endpoint_type) extensions = [ ext for ext in nova_client.discover_extensions(NOVA_API_VERSION) if ext.name == "server_external_events"] self.n_client = nova_client.Client( NOVA_API_VERSION, session=session, region_name=cfg.CONF.nova.region_name, endpoint_type=cfg.CONF.nova.endpoint_type, extensions=extensions) registry.subscribe(self._notify_subnet_created, resources.SUBNET, events.AFTER_CREATE) registry.subscribe(self._notify_subnet_updated, resources.SUBNET, events.AFTER_UPDATE) registry.subscribe(self._notify_subnet_deleted, resources.SUBNET, events.AFTER_DELETE) registry.subscribe(self._add_host_to_aggregate, resources.SEGMENT_HOST_MAPPING, events.AFTER_DELETE) registry.subscribe(self._notify_port_created, resources.PORT, events.AFTER_CREATE) registry.subscribe(self._notify_port_updated, resources.PORT, events.AFTER_UPDATE) registry.subscribe(self._notify_port_deleted, resources.PORT, events.AFTER_DELETE) def _notify_subnet_created(self, resource, event, trigger, context, subnet): segment_id = subnet.get('segment_id') if not segment_id or subnet['ip_version' != 4]: return total, reserved = self._calculate_inventory_total_and_reserved(subnet) if total: try: self._update_nova_inventory(segment_id, total, reserved) except placement_exceptions.NotFound: self._create_nova_inventory(segment_id, total, reserved, context) def _update_nova_inventory(self, segment_id, total, reserved): ipv4_inventory = self.p_client.inventories.get(segment_id, IPV4_RESOURCE_CLASS) ipv4_inventory['total'] += total ipv4_inventory['reserved'] += reserved self.p_client.inventories.update(segment_id, ipv4_inventory, IPV4_RESOURCE_CLASS) def _create_nova_inventory(self, segment_id, total, reserved, context): name = SEGMENT_NAME_STUB % segment_id resource_provider = {'name': name, 'uuid': segment_id} self.p_client.resource_providers.create(resource_provider) aggregate_id = self.n_client.aggregates.create( name, None)['aggregate']['id'] self.p_client.aggregates.associate(segment_id, [aggregate_id]) hosts_on_segment_query = context.session.query( db.SegmentHostMapping.host).filter_by(segment_id=segment_id) for host in hosts_on_segment_query: self.n_client.aggregates.add_host(aggregate_id, host) ipv4_inventory = {'total': total, 'reserved': reserved, 'min_unit': 1, 'max_unit': 1, 'step_size': 1, 'allocation_ratio': 1.0, 'resource_class': IPV4_RESOURCE_CLASS} self.p_client.inventories.create(segment_id, ipv4_inventory) def _calculate_inventory_total_and_reserved(self, subnet): total = 0 reserved = 0 allocation_pools = subnet.get('allocation_pools') or [] for pool in allocation_pools: total += int(netaddr.IPAddress(pool['end']) - netaddr.IPAddress(pool['start'])) if total: if subnet['gateway_ip']: total += 1 reserved += 1 if subnet['enable_dhcp']: reserved += 1 return total, reserved def _notify_subnet_updated(self, resource, event, trigger, context, updated_subnet, original_subnet): segment_id = updated_subnet.get('segment_id') if not segment_id or updated_subnet['ip_version' != 4]: return original_total, original_reserved = ( self._calculate_inventory_total_and_reserved(original_subnet)) updated_total, updated_reserved = ( self._calculate_inventory_total_and_reserved(updated_subnet)) total = updated_total - original_total reserved = updated_reserved - original_reserved if total or reserved: try: self._update_nova_inventory(segment_id, total, reserved) except placement_exceptions.NotFound: self._create_nova_inventory(segment_id, total, reserved, context) def _notify_subnet_deleted(self, resource, event, trigger, context, subnet): segment_id = subnet.get('segment_id') if not segment_id or subnet['ip_version' != 4]: return total, reserved = self._calculate_inventory_total_and_reserved(subnet) if total: try: self._update_nova_inventory(segment_id, total, reserved) except placement_exceptions.NotFound: pass def _add_host_to_aggregate(self, resource, event, trigger, context, host, current_segment_ids): query = context.session.query(models_v2.Subnet.segment_id).filter( models_v2.Subnet.segment_id.in_(current_segment_ids)) segment_id = query.first() if segment_id: aggregate_id = self.p_client.aggregates.list( segment_id)['aggregates'][0] self.n_client.aggregates.add_host(aggregate_id, host) def _notify_port_created(self, resource, event, trigger, context, port): # network:router_interface # network:dhcp # compute:None pass def _notify_port_updated(self, resource, event, trigger, context, updated_port, mac_address_updated, original_port): pass def _notify_port_deleted(self, resource, event, trigger, context, port, router_ids): pass

commit_message:
Replace dict.iteritems() with dict.items()

Following Python 3 guide https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Python3
Thus, we should replace task.iteritems() with task.items()

Change-Id: If617c3a87836930dc78a4ce7dd45a9b7804e0d24
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-glanceclient refs/changes/67/363367/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: task = dict([item for item in task.items() if item[0] not in ignore])
deleted_lines: task = dict([item for item in task.iteritems() if item[0] not in ignore])

subject: Run wheel build jobs in parallel and keep logs
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2017-01-24 04:44:12.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/project-config/commit/118c819063c3d616578ee0ed11d7c84ab74ebcf4', 'message': 'Run wheel build jobs in parallel and keep logs

Even after increasing the build-time to 180 minutes with
Idc1d53d1e73b4a9eb13f258f4a4d5627ec3cf300 it's not enough to avoid
timeouts.  I did a manual run and it took 214 minutes on the centos
builder.

We can parallelise builds.  The "parallel" program provides us with
plenty of useful help in this regard.  As described in the comments,
this will run ncpu jobs (4 on our builders) and capture and store the
logs for each individual job.  A test run on the centos build host was
reduced to ~1 hour.

The job output is particularly handy because we can do a little work
to make an easy-to-parse failure log.  This job is a little weird
because failures aren't hard -- we can still release everything we did
manage to build.  Initially this overview log file will enable a 3rd
party monitor that can alert interested people when failing builds
occur.

We store the build logs as a .tar.bz2 bundle as described, but the
smaller files are copied directly.

Change-Id: Ifec15f71cc3530d47da4f3304d3fe094d77e0980

commit_message:
Run wheel build jobs in parallel and keep logs

Even after increasing the build-time to 180 minutes with
Idc1d53d1e73b4a9eb13f258f4a4d5627ec3cf300 it's not enough to avoid
timeouts.  I did a manual run and it took 214 minutes on the centos
builder.

We can parallelise builds.  The "parallel" program provides us with
plenty of useful help in this regard.  As described in the comments,
this will run ncpu jobs (4 on our builders) and capture and store the
logs for each individual job.  A test run on the centos build host was
reduced to ~1 hour.

The job output is particularly handy because we can do a little work
to make an easy-to-parse failure log.  This job is a little weird
because failures aren't hard -- we can still release everything we did
manage to build.  Initially this overview log file will enable a 3rd
party monitor that can alert interested people when failing builds
occur.

We store the build logs as a .tar.bz2 bundle as described, but the
smaller files are copied directly.

Change-Id: Ifec15f71cc3530d47da4f3304d3fe094d77e0980
Depends-On: I9635721a4f8d718ad402d23600840f091267952c

commit_message:
ISO 8601 timestamps for tempurl

With this commit, the tempurl middleware accepts (besides
the traditional unix timestamps) also timestamps according
to the format '%Y-%m-%dT%H:%M:%SZ' (one acceptable form of ISO 8601).
The idea is to make the tempurls more user-friendly,
and has been formulated here:

Change-Id: I346a0241060a9559d178b30e60c957792bbeb9f0
Implements: blueprint human-readable-tempurl-timestamp

commit_message:
Unity: Add support to set IO ports in option

Add option `unity_io_ports`, which is a list of strings set by users
to specify which FC/iSCSI ports can be used by the driver.
The format is "spa_iom_0_fc0" for FC and "spa_eth0" for iSCSI.
Unix-style glob expression is supported, like "spa_*".

DocImpact
Implements: blueprint unity-add-io-port-option
Change-Id: Ifd7873b65cb06605b72af216b87846117f874868

commit_message:
Bump python-manilaclient minimal version to 1.12.0

Because it has support of API microversions implemented in Ocata
timeframe that are going to be used in other projects such as manila_ui.

Change-Id: I4d95c98f12ba24dc38339a945e507e74266cf0f1

commit_message:
Remove floating IPs in tempest config script

If cleaning leftovers from previous runs we need to remove firslty
all floating IPs.

Change-Id: Iaa8dee12a46b2ee1c9777be326e9c12c163f0667

subject: Use new parameters for the undercloud public/admin hostnames
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2017-01-24 18:49:35.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-quickstart-extras/commit/84076b16491397fcb9544bf85dc6c126a00aa154', 'message': 'Use new parameters for the undercloud public/admin hostnames

These parameters deprecated the undercloud_(public/admin)_vip
parameters and are eventually used by the keystone endpoints and the

commit_message:
Use new parameters for the undercloud public/admin hostnames

These parameters deprecated the undercloud_(public/admin)_vip
parameters and are eventually used by the keystone endpoints and the
certificate generation. they were introduced in
I53151d4f555d5d161a3e53ce5f022e3bf3b2ffbd .

Change-Id: I985d50135aa3b8fd73c2680044a44337454fc63a

Only used with SSL. (string value) # Deprecated group/name - [DEFAULT]/undercloud_admin_vip #undercloud_admin_host = 192.168.24.3 undercloud_admin_host = {{undercloud_undercloud_admin_host|default( undercloud_network_cidr|nthhost(3))}} {% endif %}

commit_message:
allow to pass options to dnsmasq service

There were request to pass parameters to dnsmasq container in kube-dns
addon.

This PR adds variable master.addons.dns.dnsmasq (dict) which can be
used to pass options to dnsmasq container. Defaults are configured in
metadata.

Change-Id: If072e31a8a1cde4c984c67373ad74d45204619b0
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/salt-formula-kubernetes refs/changes/58/424858/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: dnsmasq: cache-size: 1000 no-resolv: server: 127.0.0.1#10053 log-facility: "-"

commit_message:
use link to kubectl instead of alias

Change-Id: I04cf442fe0c6cbe523a2db1f945e8e3dd5a71356
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/salt-formula-kubernetes refs/changes/07/424707/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: /usr/bin/kubectl: file.symlink: - target: /usr/bin/hyperkube - require: - file: /usr/bin/hyperkube
deleted_lines: /root/.bashrc: file.append: - text: alias kubectl="hyperkube kubectl" - makedirs: True

subject: Add share group support to Manila client
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-06-28 16:24:13.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/python-manilaclient/commit/db4495f3b683efaba50e1b345f529e357dfd9997', 'message': 'Add share group support to Manila client

Manila needs a grouping construct that, like shares, is a 1st-class
atomic data type. Our experience with CGs has demonstrated the
complexity of adding a grouping capability, yet there are other use
cases such as migration, replication, and backup in which some
storage controllers could only offer such features on share groups.
CGs also highlighted the poor optics of an advanced feature with
comparatively little potential for vendor support. And adding new
grouping constructs for each new feature is not technically
feasible. All of the above may be addressed by generic groups,
which we think is a clean extension to the original architecture of
Manila.

This BP describes replacing the experimental CG code with client &
CLI support for the new generic share groups feature in manila.

Implements: blueprint manila-share-groups
Change-Id: I8e29baed62355fc31caeec9c7a66eaebfcbdf184
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2016-06-28 18:28:00.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/python-manilaclient/commit/3701510a13cbe2eb61f2e2ed087071365245c039', 'message': 'Add share group support to Manila client

commit_message:
Add share group support to Manila client

Manila needs a grouping construct that, like shares, is a 1st-class
atomic data type. Our experience with CGs has demonstrated the
complexity of adding a grouping capability, yet there are other use
cases such as migration, replication, and backup in which some
storage controllers could only offer such features on share groups.
CGs also highlighted the poor optics of an advanced feature with
comparatively little potential for vendor support. And adding new
grouping constructs for each new feature is not technically
feasible. All of the above may be addressed by generic groups,
which we think is a clean extension to the original architecture of
Manila.

Implements: blueprint manila-share-groups
Change-Id: I8e29baed62355fc31caeec9c7a66eaebfcbdf184

revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2017-01-18 16:10:47.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/requirements/commit/a7d70e577b237e77e91c36d1edd4849277a00e73', 'message': "Add libdeprecation

We need this library in openstacksdk in order to deprecate various APIs
in an automated fashion. We will also use it in the future to keep up
with changes in REST APIs so we can properly move with them when needed.

* Is the library actively maintained?

Yes. While it's new, it was created because it's necessary for
openstacksdk and one of the libraries it's replacing, pyrax. It has a
very small API footprint so active maintenance might not be that much,
but I'm the creator and I have a lot of need for this, as simple as it
may seem.

* Is the library good code?

Yes. It's straight-forward yet powerful, and requires no external
runtime dependencies.

* Is the library python 3 compatible?

Yes.

* Is the library license compatible?

Yes, Apache 2.0.

* Is the library already packaged in the distros we target (Ubuntu
latest / Fedora latest)?

No. It could be if this is truly needed, but I'm not entirely sure
why that is necessary for a client application. Please advise if this is
a hard requirement.

* Is the function of this library already covered by other libraries in
  global-requirements.txt?

No.

* Is the library required for OpenStack project or related dev or
  infrastructure setup?

Yes. OpenStack SDK has—and will throughout its lifetime—a need to
deprecate various parts of code as things change. As the versions of
REST APIs go through their own phases of becoming unsupported, so too
will entire packages built around those APIs. All the while, APIs
within the library will need to change for one reason or another,
and we will need to appropriately communicate that and curtail our
support over a period of time. This library does those things in an
automated fashion, improving communication while lessening the burden
to contributors.

A specific example of where this library is needed is
https://bugs.launchpad.net/python-openstacksdk/+bug/1657498

Change-Id: I8eacbfebcfce396b098fabc50861ecf50cf07acd

commit_message:
Add deprecation

We need this library in openstacksdk in order to deprecate various APIs
in an automated fashion. We will also use it in the future to keep up
with changes in REST APIs so we can properly move with them when needed.

PyPI: https://pypi.python.org/pypi/deprecation/
GitHub: https://github.com/briancurtin/deprecation

* Is the library actively maintained?

Yes. While it's new, it was created because it's necessary for
openstacksdk and one of the libraries it's replacing, pyrax. It has a
very small API footprint so active maintenance might not be that much,
but I'm the creator and I have a lot of need for this, as simple as it
may seem.

* Is the library good code?

Yes. It's straight-forward yet powerful, and requires no external
runtime dependencies.

* Is the library python 3 compatible?

Yes.

* Is the library license compatible?

Yes, Apache 2.0.

* Is the library already packaged in the distros we target (Ubuntu
latest / Fedora latest)?

No. It could be if this is truly needed, but I'm not entirely sure
why that is necessary for a client application. Please advise if this is
a hard requirement.

* Is the function of this library already covered by other libraries in
  global-requirements.txt?

No.

* Is the library required for OpenStack project or related dev or
  infrastructure setup?

Yes. OpenStack SDK has—and will throughout its lifetime—a need to
deprecate various parts of code as things change. As the versions of
REST APIs go through their own phases of becoming unsupported, so too
will entire packages built around those APIs. All the while, APIs
within the library will need to change for one reason or another,
and we will need to appropriately communicate that and curtail our
support over a period of time. This library does those things in an
automated fashion, improving communication while lessening the burden
to contributors.

A specific example of where this library is needed is
https://bugs.launchpad.net/python-openstacksdk/+bug/1657498

Change-Id: I8eacbfebcfce396b098fabc50861ecf50cf07acd

commit_message:
Fix tempest gate issue on FirewallNotFound exception

In case of failed tests the following error appears in
logs/screen-q-svc.txt.gz

  File "/opt/stack/new/neutron-fwaas/neutron_fwaas/db/firewall/v2/firewall_db_v2.py", line 805, in delete_firewall_group
    raise fw_ext.FirewallNotFound(firewall_id=id)
AttributeError: 'module' object has no attribute 'FirewallNotFound'

This exception doesn't exists anymore.
It has been replaced by FirewallGroupNotFound exception.

Closes-Bug: #1649703
Closes-Bug: #1657299
Change-Id: If97ae00f66479177f50be15361bce9e8c89afc3c
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron-fwaas refs/changes/36/424636/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: raise fw_ext.FirewallGroupNotFound(firewall_id=id) raise fw_ext.FirewallGroupNotFound(firewall_id=id)

If an IP " "address is not provided " " then one will be allocated for you." msgstr "" "IP address: " " Jika alamat IP disediakan, maka itu harus menjadi alamat IPv4 atau IPv6 " "well-formed. Jika alamat IP tidak disediakan " " maka salah satu akan dialokasikan untuk Anda." msgid "" "IP address: " " The IP address of the member to receive traffic from the load balancer. " "Must be a well-formed " " IPv4 or IPv6 address." msgstr "" "IP address: " " Alamat IP dari anggota untuk menerima lalu lintas dari penyeimbang beban. " "Harus alamat " " IPv4 atau IPv6 well-formed." msgid "" "Interval: " " The interval between health checks. Harus lebih besar dari atau sama " "dengan batas waktu (timeout)." msgid "" "Method: " " The load balancer algorithm that distributes traffic to the pool members. " "
    " "
  • " " LEAST_CONNECTIONS: Allocates requests to the instance with the least " "number of active " " connections. " "

    • " "
  • " " SOURCE_IP: Requests from a unique source IP address are consistently " "directed to the same instance. " "
    • " "
" msgstr "" "Method: " "Algoritma penyeimbang beban yang mendistribusikan lalu lintas kepada anggota " "kolam. " "

commit_message:
WIP - PCI-DSS Force users to change password upon first use

"PCI-DSS 8.2.6 Set passwords/passphrases for first-time use and
upon reset to a unique value for each user, and change immediately after
the first use" [1]

[1] https://www.pcisecuritystandards.org/documents/PCI_DSS_v3-1.pdf

Closes-Bug: #1645487
Depends-On: I90875ce2c3cf899557bb1f215fa1bda9576cbe83
Change-Id: I6f37684a4a03414beeb5f2692db4e4fe0e2ec406

added_lines: class ChangePasswordRequired(Unauthorized): message_format = _("The password must be changed for user: %(user_id)s. " "Thus, the new_password attribute must be included in " "the request for password authentication.")

commit_message:
Accurate status code vs. Backwards compatibility

This seems an important point how to keep backwards compatibility and
interoperability by comparing more accurate status code for whole
OpenStack components.

Change-Id: If673ba00f863be4a3a0ae1d6069a76131fb5491a
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/api-sig refs/changes/64/422264/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. note:: We have defined the above success codes as ideal ones, but sometimes we have already implemented different success codes on implementation side. However please do not change the existing success codes even if they are different. The changes could cause backwards incompatibility and break the OpenStack interoperability. There are two exceptions of this restriction: The first one is that we find different code and try fixing it in the same development cycle of the first API implementation. In this case, there are no users who use the API and we can avoid backwards incompatibility in actual world. The second is that we fix/change the success code by bumping a new API version. Microversions allows us to do it easily, and a major version bumping also is a good chance to change it.

commit_message:
allow to pass options to dnsmasq service

There were request to pass parameters to dnsmasq container in kube-dns
addon.

This PR adds variable master.addons.dns.dnsmasq (dict) which can be
used to pass options to dnsmasq container. Defaults are configured in
metadata.

Change-Id: I15122179f595b7d6210ee1cfbf32c7621376ce8f
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/salt-formula-kubernetes refs/changes/57/423257/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: dnsmasq: options: no-resolv: server: 127.0.0.1#10053 log-facility: "-"

commit_message:
Don't override _show_resource() for image

After refactored the method _show_resource() of
resource.Resource, we can return the response
directly if it's dict type.
This patch removes _show_resource() in image.py.

Change-Id: I95b5fd9d5dc5e6ab7fca79bed897920a5de40e7d
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/heat refs/changes/32/420532/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
deleted_lines: def _show_resource(self): if self.glance().version == 1.0: return super(GlanceImage, self)._show_resource() else: image = self.glance().images.get(self.resource_id) return dict(image)

commit_message:
Update xtrabackup version for ppc64le

This patch bumps the version of the percona xtrabackup tool for
ppc64le to match the amd64 version. A playbook for building this
in an automated way is also available on Github[1].

[1] - https://github.com/powervm/ppc64le-osa-build

Change-Id: I6b488c0b2f51b47b316ef06f0bcdc3455f05ec51
Closes-Bug: #1653962

commit_message:
func tests for tempurl iso_8601 timestamps

Change-Id: I78e25abd0ba338ba6473bf873079b877f37a974c
Signed-off-by: Thiago da Silva <thiago@redhat.com>

added_lines: from time import time, strftime, gmtimefrom swift.common.middleware import tempurl self.expires = int(time()) + 86400 self.expires_8601 = strftime( tempurl.EXPIRES_ISO8601_FORMAT, gmtime(self.expires)) for e in (str(self.expires), self.expires_8601): self.obj_tempurl_parms['temp_url_expires'] = e contents = self.env.obj.read( parms=self.obj_tempurl_parms, cfg={'no_auth_token': True}) self.assertEqual(contents, "obj contents") # GET tempurls also allow HEAD requests self.assertTrue(self.env.obj.info(parms=self.obj_tempurl_parms, cfg={'no_auth_token': True})) expires = int(time()) + 86400 expires = int(time()) + 86400 expires = int(time()) + 86400 expires = int(time()) + 86400 expires_8601 = strftime( tempurl.EXPIRES_ISO8601_FORMAT, gmtime(expires)) for e in (str(expires), expires_8601): put_parms['temp_url_expires'] = e new_obj.write('new obj contents', parms=put_parms, cfg={'no_auth_token': True}) self.assertEqual(new_obj.read(), "new obj contents") # PUT tempurls also allow HEAD requests self.assertTrue(new_obj.info(parms=put_parms, cfg={'no_auth_token': True})) expires = int(time()) + 86400 expires = int(time()) + 86400 expires = int(time()) + 86400 parms=head_parms) parms=head_parms) expires = int(time()) + 86400 expires = int(time()) + 86400 expires = int(time()) + 86400 expires = int(time()) + 86400 expires = int(time()) + 86400 expires = int(time()) + 86400 expires = int(time()) + 86400

commit_message:
Drop all eventlet support

Keystone dropped Eventlet support in Newton. This change will remove all
support for using it. Keystone will now be deployed as an apache wsgi
application. This also removes a large amount of deprecation warnings
when running keystone.

Change-Id: Ib8c14edaaa907d7f97cac73fc8e055db08830e08

commit_message:
Remove deprecated trove references

This removes the guestagent template references and in preparation for
the removal of the automatic inclusion of guestagent, it undefines
guestagent_config_file and includes guestagent directly. Once the
corresponding puppet-trove patch [1] lands, the guestagent_config_file
line can be removed.

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/392957

Change-Id: I96502e0e9c2b3720b9c55e4392623c1ff6a8dfb4
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/puppet-openstack-integration refs/changes/18/394218/5 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: guestagent_config_file => undef, } class { '::trove::guestagent': }

commit_message:
Ocata deprecation cleanup (partial)

This cleanup removes the guestagent template usage in task-manager.
Users should now configure the guestagent directly using the guestagent
class. It also removes the deprecated control_exchange parameter from
guestagent.

Change-Id: I5ecd4eda2d9171cee082af044dd8030f483399bb

deleted_lines: is_expected.to contain_file('/etc/trove/trove-guestagent.conf') context 'when set use_guestagent_template to false' do let :pre_condition do "class { 'trove': nova_proxy_admin_pass => 'verysecrete',} class { 'trove::taskmanager': use_guestagent_template => false,}" end it 'configures trove-taskmanager with trove::guestagent' do is_expected.to contain_class('trove::guestagent').with( :enabled => false, :manage_service => false, ) end end # trove taskmanager also configures trove_guestagent.conf by default, ensure rabbit is right there is_expected.to contain_file('/etc/trove/trove-guestagent.conf').with_content(/^rabbit_host=10.0.0.1$/) is_expected.to contain_file('/etc/trove/trove-guestagent.conf').with_content(/^#rabbit_port=5672$/) is_expected.to contain_file('/etc/trove/trove-guestagent.conf').with_content(/^#rabbit_ha_queues=false$/) # trove taskmanager also configures trove_guestagent.conf by default, ensure rabbit is right there is_expected.to contain_file('/etc/trove/trove-guestagent.conf').with_content(/^rabbit_host=10.0.0.1$/) is_expected.to contain_file('/etc/trove/trove-guestagent.conf').with_content(/^#rabbit_port=5672$/) is_expected.to contain_file('/etc/trove/trove-guestagent.conf').with_content(/^rabbit_ha_queues=true$/) is_expected.to contain_file('/etc/trove/trove-guestagent.conf').with_content(/^amqp_durable_queues=true$/) # trove taskmanager also configures trove_guestagent.conf by default, ensure rabbit is right there is_expected.to contain_file('/etc/trove/trove-guestagent.conf').with_content(/^rabbit_hosts=10.0.0.1,10.0.0.2$/) is_expected.to contain_file('/etc/trove/trove-guestagent.conf').with_content(/^rabbit_ha_queues=true$/)

commit_message:
bump the minimum version of openstackclient to 3.8.0

v3.8.0 of openstackclient had several critical fixes related to
incompatible changes in openstacksdk, the minimum used by the
community should be 3.8.0

Change-Id: I8b367ed1cdca1f02247403e53d6c0bb527c94030

commit_message:
remove 0.9.12 from blacklisted openstackSDK versions

The OSC team addressed the issues that were discovered in the latest
openstackSDK releases (0.9.11 and 0.9.12) with their latest OSC version,
3.7.0.

We are opting to unblock these SDK versions because we do not know when
the SDK team will release 0.9.13.

Related commits:
  6da1fafee9ec30d3d9653c64cd27f61bbfb21862
  85277c19c623e42f3c016cec099925d1be713287

Change-Id: Ib2bb2368459d6f940be59f49fb76bf147c445610

subject: Fix apt-cacher-ng file owners during rsync
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2017-01-16 15:46:16.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible-repo_server/commit/49c9be246f7f2c6d46c3f459bd12261f9db731fe', 'message': "Fix apt-cacher-ng file owners during rsync

The lsyncd service runs as the 'nginx' user such that files sync'd
from the master node to the backups will have 'nginx' as the owner.
However, the apt-cacher-ng service needs to be the owner to function
properly. This fix consolidates the pre and post sync tasks into
a script that can be called by lsyncd. The script can then change
the file owners as needed before and after the rsync.  The owners
need to be 'nginx' before the rsync so that lsyncd can update
files and 'apt-cacher-ng' after the sync so the cacher service works.

Additionally, setup lsyncd to sync each service's directory separately
rather than being rsync'd all together. This avoids lsyncd bouncing
services when their respective files are not being sync'd.

Change-Id: Ifaba17b89035398917f2b3257574e18eb9027c08
Closes-bug: #1649339
(cherry picked from commit 1169edc47be92943690983a6d10857761038b473)

commit_message:
Fix apt-cacher-ng file owners during rsync

The lsyncd service runs as the 'nginx' user such that files sync'd
from the master node to the backups will have 'nginx' as the owner.
However, the apt-cacher-ng service needs to be the owner to function
properly. This fix consolidates the pre and post sync tasks into
a script that can be called by lsyncd. The script can then change
the file owners as needed before and after the rsync.  The owners
need to be 'nginx' before the rsync so that lsyncd can update
files and 'apt-cacher-ng' after the sync so the cacher service works.

Additionally, setup lsyncd to sync each service's directory separately
rather than being rsync'd all together. This avoids lsyncd bouncing
services when their respective files are not being sync'd.

Backport modified to work with Upstart.

Change-Id: Ifaba17b89035398917f2b3257574e18eb9027c08
Closes-bug: #1649339
(cherry picked from commit 1169edc47be92943690983a6d10857761038b473)

commit_message:
Deprecate direct YAML input in tackerclient

Starting from Ocata tacker payloads will only accept
YAML dict for config and param payload values. Hence
remove the warning when something other than YAML dict
is received by the client. Such a CLI input is no longer
make sense. So, starting Ocata deprecate all direct
YAML input and remove it in Pike.

Change-Id: I03f3ac405e92d7e9fa69fd2b2761c243456fd7e8
Partial-Bug: 1656416

commit_message:
Fix hostname & initiator for volume drivers

This is a simple fix to make sure the iSCSI initiator is always returned
and the host name is generally consistent between FC and iSCSI.

Change-Id: I584b4ff4ea99b47a451e87c51c0c6ab4d0d28a0f
Closes-Bug: 1658740
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova-powervm refs/changes/90/424290/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from oslo_concurrency import lockutils from pypowervm.tasks import hdisk from pypowervm.tasks import partition from pypowervm.wrappers import virtual_io_server as pvm_vios _ISCSI_INITIATOR = None _ISCSI_LOOKUP_COMPLETE = False @lockutils.synchronized("PowerVM_iSCSI_Initiator_Lookup") def get_iscsi_initiator(adapter): """Gets the iSCSI initiator. This is looked up once at process start up. Stored in memory thereafter. :param adapter: The pypowervm adapter. :return: The initiator name. """ global _ISCSI_INITIATOR, _ISCSI_LOOKUP_COMPLETE if not _ISCSI_LOOKUP_COMPLETE: mgmt_w = partition.get_mgmt_partition(adapter) if isinstance(mgmt_w, pvm_vios.VIOS): _ISCSI_INITIATOR = hdisk.discover_iscsi_initiator( adapter, mgmt_w.uuid) _ISCSI_LOOKUP_COMPLETE = True return _ISCSI_INITIATOR

commit_message:
NetApp: Support share revert to snapshot

This commit adds support for the revert-to-snapshot feature to
the NetApp cDOT drivers for both normal and replicated shares.

Implements: blueprint netapp-cdot-share-revert-to-snapshot
Change-Id: Ia939eba03b3db9cbba0cc6c16184578e8c8893d1

commit_message:
Equal Integration Chances for all Projects

Add resolution describing cross project interactions
and reform to the current interactions.

Change-Id: I8c9c7aa93d70d2c8f8dfee448724cfedf145bb07
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/governance refs/changes/66/342366/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: =============================================== 2016-07-07 Level Playing Field for all Projects =============================================== Introduction ------------ When the :ref:`20141202-project-structure-reform-spec` spec was merged, OpenStack moved into a "Big Tent" method of governance. This was done to allow the community to grow organically, and removed the idea of a 2 tier system, where incubated projects had much more limited access to resources. As this has progressed, the load placed on horizontal teams has grown at an exponential rate. To help alleviate this quite a few horizontal projects have moved to a "plug-in" based architecture to allow more teams consume the resources available. Unfortunately, this has resulted in a patch work of things that are available to projects, and a weird collection of "core-ish" projects that are allowed in-tree, and have access to a lot of resources, and "big-tent" projects that have to use a plug-in model. This has resulted in smaller projects (or projects that were not "integrated" at the time of the reform) having to navigate a difficult path as they figure out what is allowed in-tree, what is allowed as plugins, and how they go about creating these plugins. The Path Forward ---------------- We are now at a crossroads as a community - we are starting to advertise and markert a "core" set of projects, and more of the horizontal teams are moving "big tent" projects towards plugins, while leaving "core" (not necessarily the same set of "core") projects as in-tree. We can move to a defined two tier system calling them "core" and "big tent", or we can continue with the plan from 2014 of a collection of projects that operators can pick and choose from to fill their own needs. Plugins for all --------------- As a community we decide that the OpenStack project is a collection of equal projects and as such no single project should have an advantage over others. From the `BasicDesignTenants`_ : .. epigraph:: | 4. All required components must be horizontally scalable | 6. Distribute everything As a first step towards these goals, we agree on the following core statement. For cross project interaction, a project must make the following choice: * All Projects listed in projects.yaml are allowed in tree. * All Projects listed in projects.yaml must use the same plugin interface regardless of where the plugin itself resides This does not dictate who maintains these plugins, or where the code itself resides. It does dictate that all projects have access to the same technical resources, and that no projects should have access to protected / internal APIs that are not available to the entire eco-system. .. _BasicDesignTenants: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/BasicDesignTenets

subject: x-openstack-request-id logged twice in logs
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2017-01-23 06:32:17.000000000', 'files': ['cinderclient/client.py', 'cinderclient/tests/unit/test_client.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/python-cinderclient/commit/6962056c67dca1fee2e832ff8bfbc317ed4b5ec0', 'message': 'x-openstack-request-id logged twice in logs

In the recent release of keystoneauth1 2.18.0 provision is made to log
x-openstack-request-id for session client. Once this new library is synced
in openstack projects, the x-openstack-request-id will be logged twice
on the console if session client is used.

For example,
$ cinder --debug list

DEBUG:keystoneauth:GET call to volumev2 for
http://10.232.48.204:8776/v2/61da9e4b59cf4920acc5e78438f93223/volumes/detail
used request id req-dcc22730-021e-468a-8b12-da7d58b573a7

DEBUG:cinderclient.client:GET call to volumev2 for
http://10.232.48.204:8776/v2/61da9e4b59cf4920acc5e78438f93223/volumes/detail
used request id req-dcc22730-021e-468a-8b12-da7d58b573a7

Above log will be logged twice on the console.

Removed logging of x-openstack-request-id in case of SessionClient as it
is already logged in keystoneauth1. x-openstack-request-id will only be
logged once on console if HTTPClient is used.

Depends-On: Id0693a9958d26162b7a2a40173ca28de2d3e4f62
Closes-Bug: #1657351

Change-Id: I0861212a38466d0e65cf3389c7d2757cff86ea0d
'}]
commit_message:
x-openstack-request-id logged twice in logs

In the recent release of keystoneauth1 2.18.0 provision is made to log
x-openstack-request-id for session client. Once this new library is synced
in openstack projects, the x-openstack-request-id will be logged twice
on the console if session client is used.

For example,
$ cinder --debug list

DEBUG:keystoneauth:GET call to volumev2 for
http://10.232.48.204:8776/v2/61da9e4b59cf4920acc5e78438f93223/volumes/detail
used request id req-dcc22730-021e-468a-8b12-da7d58b573a7

DEBUG:cinderclient.client:GET call to volumev2 for
http://10.232.48.204:8776/v2/61da9e4b59cf4920acc5e78438f93223/volumes/detail
used request id req-dcc22730-021e-468a-8b12-da7d58b573a7

Above log will be logged twice on the console.

Removed logging of x-openstack-request-id in case of SessionClient as it
is already logged in keystoneauth1. x-openstack-request-id will only be
logged once on console if HTTPClient is used.

Depends-On: Id0693a9958d26162b7a2a40173ca28de2d3e4f62
Closes-Bug: #1657351

Change-Id: I0861212a38466d0e65cf3389c7d2757cff86ea0d

commit_message:
Update team diversity tags

Update team diversity tags based on a recent run of the
validation script:

- Kuryr iand Octavia now have diverse-affiliation, with a
  pretty solid mix of organizations involved.

- Rally is no longer single-vendor, thanks to a recent
  increase in involvement from Fujitsu.

- Solum is no longer single-vendor, thanks to a recent
  increase in involvement from 99cloud.

- Storlets no longer has diverse-affiliation, since the
  work is mostly sustained by NTT and IBM.

Change-Id: I0937b38b3de5037ab10bb1030d9973d071dd755a

commit_message:
Use all stats while calculating reviews by company

While obtaining stats for particilar core reviewer teamstats script ignores
the case when person changes company. In this case, "stats" data in responce
obj includes more than one stat, but only first one is taken now.

This patch fixes this issue.

Change-Id: I3a588c0fc742b3e123eb32623315fdf2894ce7c9

deleted_lines: company = s.get('http://stackalytics.com/api/1.0/' 'stats/companies?metric=marks&' 'module=%s&user_id=%s&project_type=all' '&release=all&start_date=%s' % (group, eng['id'], six_months)).json()['stats'][0]['id'] companies.setdefault(company, {'reviewers': 0, 'reviews': 0}) if eng['metric'] >= MIN_REVIEWS or eng['metric'] >= min_percent: companies[company]['reviews'] += eng['metric'] companies[company]['reviewers'] += 1

commit_message:
Implementing pipeline architecture for Searchlight

As we are going to introduce publishers into Searchlight, switch to
a pipeline architecutre is needed. It gives users flexibility to
configure and control the message flow in Searchlight.

Change-Id: I0baec19047f81610593bb796f19b8f3eeda6780e
Implements: blueprint pipeline-architecture
Co-Authored-By: yuntongjin <yuntong.jin@intel.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/searchlight-specs refs/changes/24/308824/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. c) Copyright 2016 Intel Corp. Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the License); you may not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain a copy of the License at http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software distributed under the License is distributed on an AS IS BASIS, WITHOUT WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations under the License. ================================================ Pipeline Architecture ================================================ https://blueprints.launchpad.net/searchlight/+spec/pipeline-architecture This feature enables flexible pipeline architecture to allow Searchlight to configure multiple publishers to consume enhanced data. Problem Description =================== Currently when a notification comes to Searchlight, it gets processed in notification handler. The handler enriches notifications in a number of ways and indexes enriched data into Elasticsearch. This is a simple and straightforward approach because Elasticsearch is the only storage backend in Searchlight now. As we are going to introduce notification forwarder [1], this process will need to become inflexible. A pipeline architecture is needed to provide extra flexibility for users to define where enriched data is published to. Proposed Change =============== We propose that Searchlight change to a pipeline architecture to provide flexibility for forwarding notifications. The current main message flow in Searchlight is looking like the below: Source(Notifications) -> Enrichment&Index to Elasticsearch. With pipeline in place, the main message flow would look like: Source(Notifications) -> Data Transformer(Enrichment) -> Publishers(Elasticsearch, Zaqar). Data transformer may enrich notifications by many ways, like calling API service, looking up in Elasticsearch. Its goal is to turn notifications to full resource information that can be sent to pipeline publishers. It's very important to keep data consistent in the whole pipeline. All the general data enrichment should be done before populating into pipeline. Publishers should implement a method to accept enriched data, notification information, as well as an action indicated resources CURD. For example, if a nova server has been updated, publishers in the pipeline will receive server full info, server update notification and an 'update' action. It is entirely up to the publisher to decide how to deal with those information. We see Elasticsearch indexing as a case of publisher. It is default and first publisher in the pipeline. This makes indexing behavior consistent with other publishers. Data firstly comes to Elasticsearch, after indexing they are passed to other publishers in the pipeline. If indexing phase failed, no data will be sent to subsequent publishers. To achieve this, some refactors to Searchilght are needed. Currently data enrichment and Elasticsearch indexing are all happened in notification handlers. It's tight coupled and not flexible enough. We want a Elasticsearch publisher to do the indexing job. Notification handlers are focused on turning notifications to resource data. Currently Searchlight gets its data in two ways, one is incremental updates via notifications, the other is full indexing to ElasticSearch via API calls. Incremental updates are notified to all the publishers configured in the pipeline. For reindexing, it is a plugin specific feature. Plugins can decide if they want reindexing or not. A pipeline configuration file is needed, allow users to define publisher detail and configure what publishers they want to use and which notification will go to publishers. Alternatives ------------ References ========== [1] https://blueprints.launchpad.net/searchlight/+spec/notification-forwarding

commit_message:
Fix power off timings

The OpenStack commands provide a 'timeout' attribute for how long a VM
should be given for shutting down.  This patch fixes the PowerVM driver
to properly adhere to that attribute that OpenStack provides.

Change-Id: I86a26b03ce4f22f413e899bc63c6b803a7966fd9
Closes-Bug: 1562117

If not provided, will be looked up. :param add_parms: (Optional) Additional parameters. :param force_immediate: (Optional, Default False) Should it be immediately shut down. :param timeout: (Optional, Default None) How long to wait for the job to complete. If not provided, uses the base pypowervm timeout. :return: True if it was stopped. False if it was not in a stoppable state. :raises: InstancePowerOffFailure """ if timeout: power.power_off( entry, host_uuid, force_immediate=force_immediate, add_parms=add_parms, timeout=timeout) else: power.power_off( entry, host_uuid, force_immediate=force_immediate, add_parms=add_parms)

commit_message:
[verification] Introduce rally verify show-verifier command

We have a lot of information about verifiers and main horizontal table from
``rally verify list-verifiers`` command could not include all of it.

Co-Authored-By: Yaroslav Lobankov <ylobankov@mirantis.com>

Change-Id: If425e9c373483fa092ebbcefdaf9a46173275c8a

@mock.patch("rally.cli.commands.verify.envutils.get_global") def test_show_verifier(self, mock_get_global): fake_verifier = self.fake_api.verifier.get.return_value fake_verifier.uuid = "v_uuid" fake_verifier.name = "Verifier!" fake_verifier.type = "CoolTool" fake_verifier.namespace = "ExampleNamespace" fake_verifier.description = "" fake_verifier.created_at = dt.datetime(2016, 1, 1, 17, 0, 3, 66) fake_verifier.updated_at = dt.datetime(2016, 1, 1, 17, 1, 5, 77) fake_verifier.status = "installed" fake_verifier.source = "https://example.com" fake_verifier.version = "master" fake_verifier.system_wide = False fake_verifier.extra_settings = {} # It is a hard task to mock default value of function argument, so we # need to apply this workaround original_print_dict = cliutils.print_dict print_dict_calls = [] def print_dict(*args, **kwargs): print_dict_calls.append(six.StringIO()) kwargs["out"] = print_dict_calls[-1] original_print_dict(*args, **kwargs) with mock.patch.object(verify.cliutils, "print_dict", new=print_dict): self.verify.show_verifier(self.fake_api, "v_uuid") self.assertEqual(1, len(print_dict_calls)) self.assertEqual( "+----------------+---------------------+
" "| Property | Value |
" "+----------------+---------------------+
" "| UUID | v_uuid |
" "| Name | Verifier! |
" "| Description | |
" "| Type | CoolTool |
" "| Namespace | ExampleNamespace |
" "| Created at | 2016-01-01 17:00:03 |
" "| Updated at | 2016-01-01 17:01:05 |
" "| Status | installed |
" "| Source | https://example.com |
" "| Version | master |
" "| System-wide | False |
" "| Active | |
" "| Extra settings | |
" "+----------------+---------------------+
", print_dict_calls[0].getvalue()) self.fake_api.verifier.get.assert_called_once_with("v_uuid")

subject: Temporarily disable avx/avx2 on the undercloud
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2017-01-24 15:35:29.000000000', 'files': ['roles/libvirt/setup/undercloud/templates/undercloudvm.xml.j2'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-quickstart/commit/d5221dfb7a849678aba0b6bcac34b70d320bd151', 'message': 'Temporarily disable avx/avx2 on the undercloud

Workaround for https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1415831

In order to hit this, you must have a hypervisor that supports
avx/avx2.  When it fails, here's what happens...

During overcloud deployment, ironic-conductor calls qemu-img to
convert the overcloud-full.qcow2 to a raw disk.

If the undercloud is using the newer qemu-imv-ev, this contains
optimizations which utilize avx/avx2 instructions for increased
performance.

However, for presently unknown reasons (see BZ), using these
optimizations results in qemu-img failing with SIGILL (illegal
instruction).

After qemu-img fails, ironic-conductor also fails to provision the
host, and the deployment fails with a "not enough hosts" error.

Change-Id: I4960b3a48a34cb7197566de4ca249d1a80325480
'}]
commit_message:
Temporarily disable avx/avx2 on the undercloud

Workaround for https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1415831

In order to hit this, you must have a hypervisor that supports
avx/avx2.  When it fails, here's what happens...

During overcloud deployment, ironic-conductor calls qemu-img to
convert the overcloud-full.qcow2 to a raw disk.

If the undercloud is using the newer qemu-imv-ev, this contains
optimizations which utilize avx/avx2 instructions for increased
performance.

However, for presently unknown reasons (see BZ), using these
optimizations results in qemu-img failing with SIGILL (illegal
instruction).

After qemu-img fails, ironic-conductor also fails to provision the
host, and the deployment fails with a "not enough hosts" error.

Change-Id: I4960b3a48a34cb7197566de4ca249d1a80325480
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-quickstart refs/changes/01/424701/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

subject: VMware: Allow deletion of snapshot in error state
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-11-14 10:27:34.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/cinder/commit/fe627e9188f53ae35262e38685638aa4c444a8c1', 'message': "VMware: Allow deletion of snapshot in error state

The VMDK driver fails snapshot deletion if the volume is attached.
There is no need to fail the snapshot deletion if the snapshot does
not exist in the backend (for example, in cases where the snapshot
creation failed and the snapshot is in 'error' state) irrespective
of the volume state. This patch checks the existence of the snapshot
in the backend and returns if there is no backend snapshot.

Closes-bug: #1620697
Change-Id: Id9ad45435e558c4965e3d19801fedcdfa20c50b1

commit_message:
VMware: Allow deletion of snapshot in error state

The VMDK driver fails snapshot deletion if the volume is attached.
There is no need to fail the snapshot deletion if the snapshot does
not exist in the backend (for example, in cases where the snapshot
creation failed and the snapshot is in 'error' state) irrespective
of the volume state. This patch checks the existence of the snapshot
in the backend and returns if there is no backend snapshot.

Closes-bug: #1620697
Change-Id: Id9ad45435e558c4965e3d19801fedcdfa20c50b1

commit_message:
update monasca-common minimum and upper-constraint

The new release unblocks https://review.openstack.org/404878
Once the aforementioned review is merged the minimum version of
monasca-common that will be supported will be 1.4.0.  So we need
to raise the minimum version as well.

Change-Id: Ibff3fb906c7f6baee54b1199450f49b4bd174d3c

commit_message:
Fix some permissions when using Devstack

Devstack was failing to come up with a permissions error. Removing
sudo from some installations solves this bug.

commit_message:
add a tq gate check workflow for build-test-packages

ATM the build-test-packages role is not in check gate.
Changes to tq and tqe can break the role and the
devmode.sh workflow.  This role is too important
to be left ungated.

Change-Id: Ibf3447e143fef0b0f4a61faad10e63cb0e904a01

The inline examples contain double backslashes, and this creates invalid
signatures. This bugged me a second time now, so let's fix that and make
it fool proof so that I don't need to check the proxy server logs
another time for the same reason.

As the double backslashes could not be removed, and tempurl.py can not
call literalinclude, I have edited the swift documentation to only
include the terms of usage of tempurl in one section. I have removed it
from the middleware section and added any missing pieces to the 'Object
Storage v1 REST API Documentation' section. As this is a .rst file,
there is no need for the double backslashes.

If this change is accepted I will repeat the process for formpost.

Change-Id: I77e12cfd12ad998346dd42f7245b9d27124a0a97
"}, {'number': 3, 'created': '2017-01-24 08:12:38.000000000', 'files': ['swift/common/middleware/tempurl.py', 'swift/common/middleware/formpost.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/swift/commit/9b0a1ccc699966f857c66d2f3f263f65e6ca964e', 'message': "Fix inline tempurl/formpost signature examples

The inline examples contain double backslashes, and this creates invalid
signatures. This bugged me a second time now, so let's fix that and make it
fool proof so that I don't need to check the proxy server logs another time for
the same reason.

Changed the docstring to raw docstring to render the backslashes
correctly both in Python and in the restructured text, according to
http://docutils.sourceforge.net/docs/ref/rst/restructuredtext.html#escaping-mechanism

Change-Id: I77e12cfd12ad998346dd42f7245b9d27124a0a97

commit_message:
Fix inline tempurl/formpost signature examples

The inline examples contain double backslashes, and this creates invalid
signatures. This bugged me a second time now, so let's fix that and make it
fool proof so that I don't need to check the proxy server logs another time for
the same reason.

Changed the docstring to raw docstring to render the backslashes
correctly both in Python and in the restructured text, according to
http://docutils.sourceforge.net/docs/ref/rst/restructuredtext.html#escaping-mechanism

Change-Id: I77e12cfd12ad998346dd42f7245b9d27124a0a97

commit_message:
Update min version of oslo.vmware

oslo.vmware ver 2.17.0 contains a bug fix [1] required by the
VMware VMDK driver in Cinder. Updating the min version to
2.17.0.

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/352796/

Change-Id: I3de77987d8d3050d595f7e829c1dea9a7f897b32

Change-Id: Idd16d436738f75e2ee2a809be38026ca99058f18

commit_message:
Blacklist novaclient 7.0.0

Unfortunately, novaclient 7.0.0 contains several critical bugs, such
as token auth method, so we need to blacklist that version. Also min
version should be dowgraded too.

Change-Id: Idd16d436738f75e2ee2a809be38026ca99058f18

subject: Add password expiration queries for PCI-DSS
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-11-28 20:53:37.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/keystone/commit/922ce3e0419c14c232bc2f08103df7bd574d861d', 'message': '[WIP] Add password expiration queries for PCI-DSS

New queries added for determining when passwords will expires.
The following are the new queries:

/v3/users?password_expires_at={timestamp}
- Lists users whose password will expire at the given timestamp
/v3/users?password_expires_before={timestamp}
- Lists users whose password will expire before the given timestamp
/v3/users?password_expires_after={timestamp}
- Lists users whose password will expire after the given timestamp

{timestamp} is a datetime in the format "YYYY-MM-DDTHH:mm:ssZ".

Partially-Implements: pci-dss-query-password-expired-user

'}, {'number': 10, 'created': '2016-12-08 14:24:58.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/keystone/commit/846a6db5efab0629193beee8d911f4b2573d3f7c', 'message': 'Add password expiration queries for PCI-DSS

New query added for determining when passwords will expire.
The following are the new query:

/v3/users?password_expires_at={comparator}:{timestamp}
- Lists users whose password will expire based on the comparator given.

{timestamp} is a datetime in the format "YYYY-MM-DDTHH:mm:ssZ".
{comparator} is one of lt, lte, gt gte, eq, and neq to filter in.
If no comparator is given, it is treated as eq.

Partially-Implements: bp pci-dss-query-password-expired-users
Change-Id: If0b9cc3c8af92b2ea5d41a0e8afeb78e12b7689c

'}, {'number': 21, 'created': '2016-12-14 16:08:03.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/keystone/commit/74c6651aa2fbc395ceb2acfc10431c6f43aa5e65', 'message': 'Add password expiration queries for PCI-DSS

New query added for determining when passwords will expire.
The following is the new queries:

/v3/groups/{group_id}/users?password_expires_at={operator}:{timestamp}
- Lists users belonging to a group whose password will expire based
  on the operator given.
/v3/users?password_expires_at={operator}:{timestamp}
- Lists users whose password will expire based on the operator given.

{timestamp} is a datetime in the format "YYYY-MM-DDTHH:mm:ssZ".
{operator} is one of lt, lte, gt gte, eq, and neq to filter in.
If no operator is given, it is treated as eq.

Examples:
- GET /v3/users?password_expires_at=lt:2016-11-06T15:32:17Z
- GET /v3/groups/079c578fd99b428ab61fcd4c9bd88ecd/users?password_expires_at=gt:2016-12-08T22:02:00Z

Partially-Implements: bp pci-dss-query-password-expired-users
Change-Id: If0b9cc3c8af92b2ea5d41a0e8afeb78e12b7689c

commit_message:
Add password expiration queries for PCI-DSS

New query added for determining when passwords will expire.
The following are the new queries:

/v3/groups/{group_id}/users?password_expires_at={operator}:{timestamp}
- Lists users belonging to a group whose password will expire based
  on the operator given.
/v3/users?password_expires_at={operator}:{timestamp}
- Lists users whose password will expire based on the operator given.

{timestamp} is a datetime in the format "YYYY-MM-DDTHH:mm:ssZ".
{operator} is one of lt, lte, gt gte, eq, and neq to filter in.
If no operator is given, it is treated as eq.

Examples:
- GET /v3/users?password_expires_at=lt:2016-11-06T15:32:17Z
- GET /v3/groups/079c578fd99b428ab61fcd4c9bd88ecd/users?password_expires_at=gt:2016-12-08T22:02:00Z

Partially-Implements: bp pci-dss-query-password-expired-users
Change-Id: If0b9cc3c8af92b2ea5d41a0e8afeb78e12b7689c

commit_message:
Update multi-tenancy documentation

This updates the multi-tenancy documentation. The changes include:
- use the service name (e.g. the Bare Metal service) instead of the
  project name (e.g. ironic)
- fix some grammatical issues
- refer to the ironic conductor as 'ironic-conductor' instead of 'conductor'
- remove note about setting enabled_network_interfaces config option in
  ironic-api's config file; that is no longer needed since the checks
  have been moved to the conductor side (when node creation was moved).

Change-Id: Ic4b1512672c16c1bff5b43595abd90190e23b0fe

added_lines: Network interface is one of the driver interfaces that manages network switching for nodes. Configuring the Bare Metal service ================================== Below is an example flow of how to set up the Bare Metal service so that node provisioning will happen in a multitenant environment (which means using ``neutron`` network interface as stated above): ``enabled_network_interfaces`` configuration option under the ``default`` Please note that ``enabled_network_interfaces`` has to be set (to the same value) in the ironic-api configuration file too, as its value is used on the API side to check if the requested network interface is available. Keep in mind that, ideally, all ironic-conductors should have the same list of enabled network interfaces, but it may not be the case during ironic-conductor upgrades. This may cause problems if one of the ironic-conductors dies and some node that is taken over is mapped to an ironic-conductor that does not support the node's network interface. Any actions that involve calling the node's driver will fail until that network interface is installed and enabled on that ironic-conductor. ``default_network_interface`` configuration option under the ``default`` This default value will be used for all nodes that don't have a network interface explicitly specified in the creation request. commit_message:
Do not use user token in neutron client

Ironic requires admin rights in Neutron to perform certain
operations like (create provisioning/cleaning ports, unbind port,
update mac_address). Previously only admins were able to use ironic,
with keystone policy implementation it is possible that baremetal
admin doesn't have enough rights (admin rights) in Neutron with leads
to neutron operations failures.

This patch ensures that we do not pass user token to neutron client,
and always pick admin session.

Closes-Bug: #1657675

Change-Id: If17d5501062075fb8d6ca0eb4f2f38c87e2c2cc3

commit_message:
Allow customisation of AIO paths and filenames

In order to cater for implementations which 'overlay' or 'wrap'
OSA and use the AIO bootstrap process, the following changes
are implemented:

- The paths to source the configuration files and scripts are
  now customisable so that the role may be executed by a
  playbook that is not in the OSA repository.
- The path of the conf.d files may be provided to the role in
  order to allow conf.d files to be sourced from outside the
  OSA repository.
- The resulting file names for the user_variables and
  user_secrets configuration are now customisable.

Change-Id: I453342c88a6768641c96e3ff174aaeec5d554845

commit_message:
Test plan for workloads

 * Initial data, description of used environment and tests
 * [WIP]

Change-Id: Ib3282217b75ab912edb906fee150084e10c03dba
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/performance-docs refs/changes/50/413650/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. _Workload_to_emulate_end-user_traffic: ==================================== Workload to emulate end-user traffic ==================================== :status: **draft** :version: 1.0 :Abstract: This document describes a test plan for running workloads outside of the OpenStack cloud to emulate end-user traffic. :Conventions: - **Kubernetes:** is an open-source system for automating deployment, scaling, and management of containerized applications. - **Calico:** is a new approach to virtual networking and network security for containers, VMs, and bare metal services, that provides a rich set of security enforcement capabilities running on top of a highly scalable and efficient virtual network fabric. Calico includes pre-integration with Kubernetes and Mesos (as a CNI network plugin), Docker (as a libnetwork plugin) and OpenStack (as a Neutron plugin). - **fuel-ccp:** CCP stands for "Containerized Control Plane". The goal of this project is to make building, running and managing production-ready OpenStack containers on top of Kubernetes an easy task for operators. - **OpenStack:** OpenStack is a cloud operating system that controls large pools of compute, storage, and networking resources throughout a datacenter, all managed through a dashboard that gives administrators control while empowering their users to provision resources through a web interface. - **Heat:** Heat is a service to orchestrate composite cloud applications using a declarative template format through an OpenStack-native REST API. - **Nodes:** are servers used for workloads. - **Slice:** are set of 6 VMs: #) 1x Yahoo! Benchmark (ycsb) #) 1x Cassandra #) 1x Magento #) 1x Wordpress #) 2x Idle VM Test Plan ========= The test plan is executed against slices deployed using Heat. Test Environment ---------------- Preparation ^^^^^^^^^^^ 1. To be able to run test we need: - K8s cluster installed and configured with Calico - OpenStack cloud with Heat installed on top of K8s cluster - A node is outside OpenStack cloud with Locust.IO .. table:: Software to be installed +-----------------+------------+------------------------------------------+ | software | version | source | +=================+============+==========================================+ | `Kargo`_ | master | quay.io/coreos/hyperkube:v1.4.3_coreos.0 | +-----------------+------------+------------------------------------------+ | `Kubernetes`_ | 1.4.3 | quay.io/coreos/hyperkube:v1.4.3_coreos.0 | +-----------------+------------+------------------------------------------+ | `calico`_ | 0.22.0 | docker hub | +-----------------+------------+------------------------------------------+ | `calicoctl`_ | 1.0.0-beta | docker hub | +-----------------+------------+------------------------------------------+ | `OpenStack`_ | newton | From sources | +-----------------+------------+------------------------------------------+ | `Locust.io`_ | newton | From sources | +-----------------+------------+------------------------------------------+ Environment description ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^ Test results MUST include a description of the environment used. The following items should be included: - **Hardware configuration of each server.** If virtual machines are used then both physical and virtual hardware should be fully documented. An example format is given below: .. table:: Description of server hardware +-------+----------------+-------+-------+ |server |name | | | | +----------------+-------+-------+ | |role | | | | +----------------+-------+-------+ | |vendor,model | | | | +----------------+-------+-------+ | |operating_system| | | +-------+----------------+-------+-------+ |CPU |vendor,model | | | | +----------------+-------+-------+ | |processor_count | | | | +----------------+-------+-------+ | |core_count | | | | +----------------+-------+-------+ | |frequency_MHz | | | +-------+----------------+-------+-------+ |RAM |vendor,model | | | | +----------------+-------+-------+ | |amount_MB | | | +-------+----------------+-------+-------+ |NETWORK|interface_name | | | | +----------------+-------+-------+ | |vendor,model | | | | +----------------+-------+-------+ | |bandwidth | | | +-------+----------------+-------+-------+ |STORAGE|dev_name | | | | +----------------+-------+-------+ | |vendor,model | | | | +----------------+-------+-------+ | |SSD/HDD | | | | +----------------+-------+-------+ | |size | | | +-------+----------------+-------+-------+ - **Configuration of physical network.** The description of phisical and logical connectivities. - **Configuration of virtual machines and virtual networks (if used).** The configuration files can be attached, along with the mapping of virtual machines to host machines. - **Kubernetes + Calico configuration** Deployment scheme and configuration of servers used within testing environment. #) k8s nodes configuration and roles #) k8s networking configuration (Calico) - **OpenStack deployment configuration used by fuel-ccp.** OpenStack services configuration and topology used by fuel-ccp. #) OpenStack services and roles topology Test Case: Monitoring of the cloud under load --------------------------------------------- Description ^^^^^^^^^^^ The goal of this test is to investigate OpenStack and Kuburnetes behavior under load. We are interested in the following metrics: CPU user, CPU system, Disk statistics, Network load, Memory used and IO stat per device on each controller nodes and one of the compute node. Parameters ^^^^^^^^^^ .. table: +-----------------------------+------------------------+ | Parameter name | Value | +=============================+========================+ | value of slices | 4, 10 | +-----------------------------+------------------------+ | CPU Oversubscription ratio: | 1:1; 1:2,4; | +-----------------------------+------------------------+ List of performance metrics ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^ The tables below shows the list of test metrics to be collected. The priority is the relative ranking of the importance of each metric in evaluating the performance of the system. .. table:: List of performance metrics for workloads +--------------------+------------------------------------------+ | Value | Description | +====================+==========================================+ | || | | CPU user || | | || | | || | +--------------------+------------------------------------------+ | || | | CPU system || | | || | | || | +--------------------+------------------------------------------+ | || | | Disk statistics || | | || | | || | +--------------------+------------------------------------------+ | || | | Network load || | | || | | || | +--------------------+------------------------------------------+ | || | | Memory used || | | || | | || | +--------------------+------------------------------------------+ | || | | IO stat per device || | | || | | || | +--------------------+------------------------------------------+ Measuring performance values ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^ Workloads performance testing will be based on emulating end-user traffic against application from slices, such as Cassandra, Wordpress and Magento. - 1. `Heat templates`_ could be launched with different set of parameters: #) *slice_count* - amount of slices to be spawned #) *server_image* - image to be used for instances #) *server_host* - number of compute node #) *start_ip* - first two number of ip address for new subnets #) *public_net_id* - external network to be used for floating IPs #) *router_id* - ID of the router - 2. Parameters for deploy script: #) *NODE_FROM* - start number of compute node for deploying slice #) *NODE_TO* - end number of compute node for deploying slice #) *COUNT* - amount of slices to be spawned (default 2) #) *IP_START* - start number for new subnets (default 11) Applications ============ Heat templates -------------- .. literalinclude:: heat/common.yaml :language: yaml .. literalinclude:: heat/sliceOnNode.yaml :language: yaml .. literalinclude:: heat/slice.yaml :language: yaml Script for deploying slice via Heat ----------------------------------- .. literalinclude:: heat/run_slices.sh :language: bash .. references: .. _kargo: https://github.com/kubernetes-incubator/kargo .. _Kubernetes: http://kubernetes.io/ .. _calico: https://github.com/projectcalico/calico-containers/releases/tag/v0.22.0 .. _calicoctl: https://github.com/projectcalico/calico-containers/releases/tag/v1.0.0-beta .. _OpenStack: http://www.openstack.org/ .. _fuel-ccp: http://fuel-ccp.readthedocs.io/ .. _Locust.io: https://github.com/locustio/locust/releases/tag/v0.7.5 Reports ======= Test plan execution reports:

commit_message:
New Applier Workflow Engine

This patch set allows to execute Watcher Actions in parallel.
New config option max_workers sets max number of threads
to work.

Implements: blueprint parallel-applier
Change-Id: Ie4f3ed7e75936b434d308aa875eaa49d49f0c613

commit_message:
Define OSC plugin command namespaces

We decided to adopt OSC plugin approach for networking advanced services
or similar stuffs. This patch proposes command namespaces for them.

Change-Id: I614ffe20bb84837ed7e757f1e4a4bb0e332e2d3b
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-neutronclient refs/changes/04/320604/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: Which CLI do I change? ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~Where does my CLI belong? ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~Users of the neutron client's command extensions must adopt the `OSC plugin <https://github.com/openstack/python-openstackclient/blob/master/doc/source/plugins.rst>`_ system for this transition. Such users will maintain their OSC plugin within their own project and should follow the guidance in the table above to determine which command to change. Adding commands to OpenStack Client ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ Plugin command name structure ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ This list is used to reserve command namespaces for advanced networking servives. +-----------------------------+------------------------------+ | Category | Command namespace | +=============================+==============================+ | LBaaS v2 | ``network loadbalancer xxx`` | +-----------------+-----------+------------------------------+ | Dynamic Routing | BGP stuff | ``network bgp xxx`` | | +-----------+------------------------------+ | | Others | (coming later) | +-----------------+-----------+------------------------------+ | VPNaaS | ``network vpn xxx`` | +-----------------------------+------------------------------+ | FWaaS v2 | ``network firewall xxx`` | +-----------------------------+------------------------------+
deleted_lines: **Which CLI do I change?****Where does my CLI belong?**Users of the neutron client's command extensions must adopt the `OSC plugin <https://github.com/openstack/python-openstackclient/blob/master/doc/source/plugins.rst>`_ system for this transition. Such users will maintain their OSC plugin within their own project and should follow the guidance in the table above to determine which command to change.

commit_message:
Modify ALLOWED_HOSTS doc in Horizon install guide

This patch modifies the ALLOWED_HOSTS setting that is presented in the
Horizon install guide, as well as highlighting the previous setting and
a link to further information in the Django docs.

Change-Id: I9c35160da847e6bd41953ffe9983f6d999f90c49
